item.title: Learner Profile
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded:
Hello! I'm Shaafi, nice to see you visiting my page! Here's a short introduction for myself. I am studying in the Computer Science program because working with computers, especially coding/debugging, is the most frustrating but provides the satisfaction once done right. My hobbies include playing land sports (I drown in water easily) such as soccer, basketball, table tennis, volleyball and much more. I also like hanging out with friends, whether it be going to the gym or to a social gathering. I love working in groups. The fact that multiple group members bring in different perspectives together to create a product is a great idea. I prefer working in a group as it is more organised, scheduled, and everyone can keep each other updated and on task.
I have previously taken EDCI337 and EDCI338 courses and have thoroughly enjoyed them based on their contents. And now here I am taking EDCI339, excited to learn about various forms of distributed and open learning and related topics including its history and evolution. I am excited to explores communities in online spaces and work with and across emerging forms of modality such as blended and multi-access learning. This course would help me understand how to work network learning into my studies which is what today is all about.
Looking forward to get into the course and start collaborating!

item.title: Module 1 Learning Activity: Theories of Learning
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Tony Bates, an expert in the field of online learning and distance education, extensively discusses the 4 theories of learning: Behaviourism, Cognitivism, Constructivism, and Connectivism. An understanding of learning theories helps teachers connect to all different kinds of students. Teachers can focus on different learning styles to reach different students, creating teaching that focuses directly on student needs and aptitudes. Let's dive deeper into these theories.

1. Behaviourism

Behaviourism is based on the notion that students repeat certain behaviours depending on the reinforcement they receive. It is the idea that all behaviours are acquired through conditioning, and conditioning occurs through interaction with the environment. One of the most common example of behaviourism, that I have experienced as well, is when teachers reward students or the entire class with a reward for good behaviour or getting a good grade. The same concept is used with punishments as well. Most teachers use this example with a younger demographic of students as the kids are the most responsive to this stimulus while showing the most change. When I was younger, my teacher would give us a star every time we scored 100% on the spelling test. Once we received the star, we could trade it in for a candy bar which motivated us to study hard every week. Not only did I get full scores on the test that made my teacher and parents happy, but I also got a candy bar every week!

2. Cognitivism

Cognitivism focuses on how information is received, organized, stored and retrieved by the mind. It uses the mind as an information processor, that helps to understand how thought processes influence learning. Reflecting on one's experience is an important method of learning using the cognitive learning strategies. I've had to write reflections all the way from middle school up until now in university. It is about questioning, in a positive way, what you do and why you do it and then deciding whether there is a better, or more efficient, way of doing it in the future. This allows people to think back on and learn from their experiences, constructing new knowledge and applying that knowledge to new experiences. I have no doubt that I'll still be reflecting in the future.

3. Constructivism

Constructivism is an important learning theory based on the idea that learners are actively building on their existing foundation to learn new information. It promotes social and communication skills by creating a classroom environment that emphasizes collaboration and exchange of ideas. Students must learn how to articulate their ideas clearly as well as to collaborate on tasks effectively by sharing in group projects. One way to put constructivism to use is by asking students to explain new material in their own words. This method of learning can assist them in assimilating an idea by forcing them to re-express the new ideas in their existing vocabulary. My physics teacher would teach us a topic then ask us to get into small groups to explain the same concept to one another for clarification. This allowed us to clarify doubts amongst ourselves and also help answer others' questions that built a good understand of the concept in order to understand the next part of the lesson as it was connected to the previous.

4. Connectivism

Connectivism is a relatively new learning theory that suggests students should combine thoughts, theories, and general information in a useful manner. It accepts that technology is a major part of the learning process and that our constant connectedness gives us opportunities to make choices about our learning. Uvic Brightspace courses have a forum page where students join together to ask and answer questions to learn from one another. This is a great example of using technology to share thoughts, theories and general information about a certain course. Moreover, there are many other spaces/platforms where students get together to study, like the Uvic discord server. The discord server is a regulated space for each and every course where hundreds of students attend to talk to one another.

I chose this prompt as it was an interesting read!

These theories are important because even without formal training or knowledge of different theories of learning, all teachers and instructors will approach teaching within one of these main theoretical approaches, whether or not they are aware of the educational jargon surrounding these approaches. With a knowledge of alternative theoretical approaches, teachers and instructors are in a better position to make choices about how to approach their teaching in ways that will best fit the perceived needs of their students, within the very many different learning contexts that teachers and instructors face.

item.title: Module 2 Learning Activity: Mapping your Learning Network
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded: Connectivism is built on the idea that digital technology brings people together and creates new learning opportunities. It suggests students should combine thoughts, theories, and general information in a useful manner. This goes hand in hand with the concept of networked learning. Networked learning refers to a method of collaborative internet-based education whereby learners can connect with resources, teachers and other students. Weller discusses that by the late 2000s, with the advent of greater connectivity, user-generated content, and social media; a number of educators are now exploring the possibilities of education in a more networked, connected model. Siemens defined connectivism as “the integration of principles explored by chaos, network, and complexity and self-organization theories. Here is an image of my Network Map: Looking back at this map as a whole, I've realized that I learn from every aspect of my life; whether it be from somewhere expected like school or from somewhere unexpected like family (from helping my dad build his business on Facebook using my computer science knowledge). There is no single, correct set of objects of knowledge whereby education occurs through the transferral of knowledge from educator to learner, but rather knowledge and people are distributed, and it is the process of engagement with these that constitutes learning. There is an unlimited number of resources on the internet that is open and free for anyone to study from. From looking at my map, I now see that I can physically learning anywhere because I have the internet at the tip of my fingertips. Years ago, people had to search through books in libraries to find information but now that we are practicing connectivism in person and on the internet where people are sharing their thoughts, theories and ideas for others to be interested in which leads to a greater drive to learn. The internet, to me, is one of the best inventions by mankind because now, it allows anyone to access any information to aid knowledge. I chose to write about this prompt because Connectivism and Learning Network play a major part of my life. I, as a computer science student, learn about the internet and how information is being accessed throughout the world at a click of a button; and also how we can improve networked systems. Earlier in the course, I learnt about connectivism which I can now connect to learning networks that I learnt about a few months go in my other course, EDCI338. Both concepts motivates learning when peers are connected and share opinions, viewpoints, and ideas through a collaborative process. Connectivism and networked learning allows people to legitimize what they're doing, so knowledge can be spread over the internet more quickly through multiple resources which I believe is a great step into the future.

item.title: Module 3 Learning Activity: Architectures of Control
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded:
Slack as a frequent digital space for education. This term, I've used slack for two of my courses, CSC370 and EDCI339 and I've come to learn it is an amazing education technology that we use to control access of information, controlling behaviour and controlling learning. I will be talking about my CSC370 Slack space:
1. What are you able to do?
Slack allows us to be able to communicate with the instructors, professors, TAs and fellow classmates about any questions or concerns we have about the course or assignments. The whole platform is divided into channels. You can either directly message a professor if there is something personal to talk about or you can also discuss assignment questions in the assignment channel, or talk about a concept in the general channel. You can also use the calling system to set up a meeting if needed.
2. What are you prevented from doing?
In our CSC370 assignments channel, we aren't able to share answers due to academic integrity regulations but we are encouraged to talk about any errors/questions we have about the assignments. For example, students will post the error messages they get when they run their code in the assignment channel and a professor or fellow classmate will reply to answer the question as they might have been through the same difficulty.
3. How does this impact your experience in the space?
I've had a great experience with the space and it has had a good impact on me personally. I've used the assignment channel multiple times to ask about a query error I've had with the SQL assignments. I've also been able to meet and study with a few peers that I met over the channels which made studying and understanding concepts easier.
4. How might this impact the design of learning experiences?
The main difference between the learning design of Slack and traditional way of learning in person is that Slack is an online technology while we've been raised to study in a classroom in person. I believe both have their advantages and disadvantages which have their own learning experiences but online learning has become more prevalent recently. Some students prefer learning in person and taking in that learning experience while others like a more online learning experience, but at the end of the day it depends on the learner's preference.
5. How might this impact the student-teacher relationship?
There might be differences in an in-person student-teacher relationship while connecting online but they both require communication. I believe Slack has a wonderful way to connect students and teachers anytime anywhere as it is an online messaging platform.
 
Reflection:
I feel like Slack is a great messaging app that connects people to the information they need. By bringing people together to work as one unified team, Slack is one of the newer platform that have revolutionised the way of communication, just like Discord. It is simple, easy to use, and does the job efficiently. I believe it has been a great addition into the education systems as it makes communication easier and more available.

item.title: Module 4 Learning Activity: MOOCs
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) are free online courses available for anyone to enroll. I've joined a MOOC on Udemy and I learned about HR Analytics: How To Create An HR Dashboard Using Excel.  1. Provide a short description of the MOOC – what was the topic? how was it organized? what interactions were available? how were you assessed? It is a course that uses Excel for HR Analytics, calculates HR metrics, builds HR dashboards & ML models for Human Resource & People Analytics. There is a description talking about "why you should choose this course", "what makes us qualified to teach you", and most importantly "what is covered in this course" with an in depth explanation of each of the 7 chapters included. You are able to message the instructor about any question in any parts of the course which, similar to an online messaging system. The only way you were accessed was by a bar that shows the percentage completion of the course. There are no assignments but recommend following along yourself. 2. How did this learning experience compare to ‘traditional’ courses? Consider any of the following factors: One of the obvious differences is taking the class online instead of the traditional in person classes. However, I believe the method of learning is completely up to the learner's preference. I had a great time learning from this course as I was ensured of their legitimacy, it was flexible so there was no pressure, the learning experience was achieved as their explanations were easy to understand and follow. However, there was definitely some lack of connection with the instructors as they are not able to message back immediately but they do explain it as clearly as possible. 3. Do you think this MOOC would be considered an xMOOC or a cMOOC? This MOOC is considered xMOOC as it is delivered by an instructor to the student — the key distinction between the xMooc and cMooc. 4. Based on your experiences, would you consider the MOOC that you completed to be “Open”? If so, in what sense of the word? If not, why not? It is open to some extent. It is available for anyone to access on the digital space (whether it be Udemy or Coursera), but it comes at a monetary cost. It is considered open for the people who have a computer and the ability to spend about 20 - 50 dollars on a proper online course. However, it is not considered open to the people who do not have the financial ability to pursue a MOOC. Reflection: All in all, I believe open education has further flourished in the past few years due to being forced to stay indoors. Online education is a great way for the majority to access education and learning that many are not able to afford or pursue. I chose this activity because I wanted to share my experience as someone who has experienced a MOOC and wanted to give my perspective on it. I believe online learning has a future as it is more affordable and available than the current 'traditional' schooling systems.

item.title: Module 5 Learning Activity: Metaphorically Speaking
item.dc:creator: shaafij
item.content:encoded:
I found a metaphor on Forbes that said, "Within a garden, the seeds are the most important and fundamental element, much like the students within the classroom. Seeds grow and flourish over time with the assistance of the gardener, much like students grow and learn within a classroom with the support of the teacher."

Visualization:

  1. Explaining the metaphor, why you selected it and its significance in education and discuss whether or not you think that the metaphor is appropriate or flawed I believe this metaphor is appropriate and accurate. The reason I picked this metaphor is because it this beautiful piece of saying entails the concept of togetherness that I believe in. Having a supervisor or guardian is essential in life, whether they are a parent, teacher or even a friend. The gardening metaphor suggests that the school is a garden, a child is a plant, and a teacher is a gardener. Each plant has its own temperature regimen, humidity, and harvest time. The growth potential is within the seed, and all we need is to provide nutrients that allow it to express itself. 2. Reflecting on what impact this metaphor may have on policy, practice, and your own understanding of the topic or phenomenon As previously mentioned, I believe that this metaphor is an accurate representation of growth. We learn by ourselves to a certain extent, however having someone to look up to and learn from is also another form of growth. I've had personal connection to this metaphor because I'm still meeting people (friends and academic advisors) today who inspire me to grow as a person to strive for a great potential. Reflection: There are so many metaphors around that help us visualize and convey our mental models (the intuitive frameworks we carry in our mind that help us interpret the world) in a concise manner. Metaphors give us a chance to ponder, understand and adjust our assumptions and knowledge. This learning activity reminded me that I get to choose to accept what I believe. I've been exposed to many metaphors/information that has given me a deeper understanding of a concept in an accurate manner and there are also other metaphors that have flawed meaning behind them. References: Forbes talk about "How Metaphors Shape Our Ideas About Education", retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/juliabrodsky/2021/04/01/how-metaphors-shape-our-ideas-about-education/?sh=5d532881495a
